awd_titl_txt: Engineering nanoparticles and nanostructures with precise and tunable modalities of interaction with the autophagy-lysosome system
awd_abstract_narration:
Nanotechnology has led to improvements in many products. These include electronic displays, computer memory chips, lithium ion batteries, whiteners, and stronger carbon fibers, to name a few. Human exposure to these particles has skyrocketed in recent years. Surprisingly, human cells are able to take up and process these particles.  This project will investigate the effect that these types of particles have on human cell metabolism.  The project will also engage with local area high school students, and HS teachers, many who serve underrepresented minority (URM) populations. Doing so will strengthen the science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) infrastructure, encourage greater participation in STEM careers by URM students, and support the expansion of a high-tech workforce in biomanufacturing.

A variety of engineered nanomaterials (ENMs) are processed by pathways evolved to recycle and degrade intracellular nano-sized materials. Evidence points to the activation of the autophagy-lysosome (AL) system as an adaptive response to ENM uptake. We hypothesize that the AL system responds to ENMs through molecular mechanisms similar to those activated in response to natural nanomaterials. Inspired by the rules of naturally occurring nanomaterials, this project will 1) generate synthetic nanoparticles and genetically encoded nanostructures that mimic natural nanosized particles and their autophagy-evoking mechanisms; 2) elucidate the impact of these novel bio-inspired nanomaterials on the lysosomal system by monitoring lysosomal biogenesis, function, and integrity; and 3) characterize the response to these bio-inspired nanomaterials by utilizing in vitro model systems specially designed to evaluate the impact of ENMs on every step of this pathway.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
A variety of engineered nanomaterials are processed by uptake and routing pathways evolved to recycle and degrade intracellular nano-sized materials; these pathways converge to the autophagy-lysosome system. Indeed, a growing body of evidence points to the activation of the autophagy-lysosome system as a stress or adaptive response to engineered nanomaterial uptake. 

The autophagy-lysosome system plays a vital role in maintaining cellular homeostasis and survival. Activated by environmental factors, such as nutrient depletion and invading pathogens, and intracellular stimuli, such as the accumulation of waste material, the autophagy-lysosome system provides a highly dynamic quality control mechanism to recycle cellular components and eliminate unwanted and toxic materials. The main cellular catabolic pathway, the autophagy-lysosome system is at the forefront of the cellular response to a variety of nanosized materials encountered by the cell, including engineered nanomaterials, and thus affects the subsequent interactions of engineered nanomaterials with other cellular components.

Due to its fundamental homeostatic function, engineered nanomaterial-induced alterations in this degradation system may have deleterious consequences on cells and possibly lead to a variety of adverse effects at the organismal levels, reflecting the heterogeneous and complex properties of nanomaterials themselves. Deciphering the interplay between engineered nanomaterials and the autophagy-lysosome system is thus crucial to understanding the impact of engineered nanomaterials on cell physiology and designing safe engineered nanomaterials.

Our studies show that the response of the autophagy-lysosome system to engineered nanomaterial uptake and the outcomes of this response on cell physiology vary dramatically depending on the properties of the engineered nanomaterials, including charge and surface modifications, and may culminate in the enhancement of cellular clearance or blockage of autophagic flux and, possibly, cell death. These data provide important insights into the design rules of engineered nanomaterials with autophagy-modulating properties for the first time. We found that the autophagy-lysosome system responds to engineered nanomaterials through molecular mechanisms similar to those activated in response to natural nanomaterials, such as protein and lipid aggregates and nanostructures derived from invading bacterial pathogens. We generated synthetic nanoparticles and genetically encoded nanostructures that mimic natural nanosized particles and their autophagy-evoking mechanisms through the formation of aggregated structures and display of protein and lipid signaling molecules known to interact with components of the autophagy system. We studied the impact of these novel bio-inspired nanomaterials on the lysosomal system by monitoring lysosomal biogenesis, function, and integrity, which are often affected by the uptake of engineered nanomaterials. Finally, we characterized the autophagic response to these bio-inspired nanomaterials by capitalizing on a comprehensive experimental pipeline of in vitro model systems specially designed to evaluate the impact of engineered nanomaterials on every step of this fundamental homeostatic pathway, from transcriptional modulation to clearance.

This study generated nanomaterials that exert precise and tunable interactions with the autophagy-lysosome system. Results from this study advanced our fundamental understanding of the response of the autophagy-lysosome system to nanosized structures and particles. 

By defining the design rules for generating engineered nanomaterials with precise autophagy-modulating properties, this study provided much-needed tools to modulate this important cell homeostatic system. Results from this study will inform the design of delivery vectors, diagnostics, nanotherapeutics, and any engineered nanomaterials expected to come in contact with humans. This research program also provided broadly reaching educational and training opportunities to students belonging to underrepresented groups to increase diversity in STEM. Specifically, this research program was leveraged 1) to provide training, research, and mentoring opportunities for high school teachers and students from the Greater Houston area, 2) to improve teaching and learning for college students, and 3) to build the university infrastructure that supports the career development of faculty and post-doctoral fellows.

 

 

 

 


Last Modified: 10/31/2022
Modified by: Laura Segatori
